patches.reasoning: The prior knowledge section is added to ensure pupils have the foundational understanding necessary to grasp the new concepts introduced in this lesson.

value: Romans occupied Britain for nearly 400 years.
Roman Britain was part of the Roman Empire.
Roman soldiers built roads and towns in Britain.
Romans introduced new technologies and ideas to Britain.

patches.reasoning: Key learning points are added to highlight the main concepts that pupils should understand by the end of the lesson.

value: The Roman Empire withdrew from Britain around AD 410.
Britain faced invasions from other groups like the Saxons after the Romans left.
The Roman departure led to changes in governance and society in Britain.

patches.reasoning: Adding misconceptions helps to identify common misunderstandings and provide guidance on how to address them in the lesson.

value.misconception: The Romans left Britain because they were defeated by the British.
value.description: The Romans left Britain mainly due to pressures in their own empire, not because of defeat by the British.

value.misconception: Roman culture disappeared immediately after they left Britain.
value.description: Roman influences remained in Britain for many years after their departure, including in architecture and technology.

patches.reasoning: Keywords are added to ensure pupils understand and can use specific vocabulary related to the lesson topic.

value.definition: An ancient empire that ruled over large parts of Europe, including Britain.
A group of people who invaded Britain after the Romans left.
The act of leaving or pulling back, like the Romans leaving Britain.
